customer_name: ADVENTURE GOLF AT REMPELS GROVE LLC
site_name: ADVENTURE GOLF AT REMPELS GROVE LLC

citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure fence-line that houses domestic goats and fallow deer does not have any public barriers present.
Upon arrival to the facility 2 groups of people were observed by the inspector petting goats through this fence. The public
feeding station does have barriers present, but a young goat was observed on the public side of the barrier being touched
and fed by patrons. Failure to provide public barriers increases the risk of harm to both the animals and the public. The
licensee must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and the public. Additionally,
there must be sufficient distance between and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public so as to
assure the safety of the animals and the public. Correct by, 15-March-2023.

The facility did not have any readily identifiable employees or attendants present during periods of public contact. The
inspector observed two groups of people touching and feeding goats through the fence-line of a primary enclosure that
housed domestic goats and fallow deer. In the feeding station a young goat also was being fed and touched when it
crossed the public barrier in the feeding station. Failure to have a knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee
present during public contact creates a risk to both the animals and the public. The licensee must ensure that a
responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee is present at all times during periods of public contact.
Correct by, 04-March-2023.

An enclosure housing 16 fallow deer and 30 domestic goats has multiple areas of their primary enclosure fence that
require repair. There is an area on the back side of the fence that the wire fencing is sagging approximately a foot from
the top support beam. On the bottom of the same section, wire fencing has been pulled away and wood has been added
to cover the area. Another part of the fence has a severely bent top support from a tree falling on it making the top of the
fence closer to the ground than originally intended. Failure to maintain primary enclosure fencing can allow for animal
entrapment in loose areas, sharp points from broken or improperly secured wire, and the possibility for animal escape
and/or outside animal entry. The licensee must ensure that the housing facilities are constructed of such material and of
such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. Additionally, the housing facilities shall be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury and to safely contain the animals. Correct by, 24-March-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End Section
